questions.question: She couldn’t qualify for the race ……………………….. having trained very hard.
questions.description: In spite of is a preposition. It can be followed by an ing form.

questions.question: He couldn’t pass the exam ………………………… he worked very hard.
questions.description: Although is a conjunction. It is followed by a clause. In spite of and despite are prepositions.

questions.question: She sat …………………….. me across the table.
questions.description: In front of does not mean ‘across a table from.’ That idea is expressed with opposite or facing.

questions.question: ………………………… did he start going out with her than she fell in love with another guy.
I was hardly inside the house …………………….. the lights went out.
questions.description: Hardly can be followed by when or before.

questions.question: ………………………….. had I closed my eyes when the dog started barking.
questions.description: Both hardly and scarcely can be followed by when or before.

questions.question: She has been a go-getter ……………………… her childhood.
questions.description: From is possible with a present perfect tense in expressions that mean ‘right from the start’.

questions.question: The shop was open ……………………………. the morning.
questions.description: Since is usually used with a present perfect tense. From is used with simple tenses.

questions.question: We had to cancel the picnic ……………………………….. bad weather.
questions.description: Due to and owing to both mean because of.

questions.question: He doesn’t care …………………………. his appearance.
questions.description: If you care about something, it interests or worries you.

questions.question: She is ………………………….. the Harvard School of Business.
questions.description: We use at to say where people study.

questions.question: I won’t be leaving ………………………… Friday.
questions.description: Not until means the same as not before.
